review.title: Conditions for Normative Decision Making at the Fire Ground
review.abstract: We discuss the changes in an attitude to decision making at the fire ground. The changes are driven by the recent technological shift. The emerging new approaches in sensing and data processing (under common umbrella of Cyber-Physical Systems) allow for leveling off the gap, between humans and machines, in perception of the fire ground. Furthermore, results from descriptive decision theory question the rationality of human choices. This creates the need for searching and testing new approaches for decision making during emergency. We propose the framework that addresses this need. The primary feature of the framework are possibilities for incorporation of normative and prescriptive approaches to decision making. The framework also allows for comparison of the performance of decisions, between human and machine.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In this section we outline the main obstacles to tackling the problem. Fire attracts many researchers from different fields. This very complex decision-making environment is often seen as the iron wall for many approaches from decision theory and artificial intelligence. Vaguely defined goals, high uncertainty, dynamically changing conditions, time and resources are limited to tackling the problem.

sections.heading: 2 Ill-informed Machines

sections.heading: 4 Normative Approach to Decision Making
sections.text: In this section, we propose a framework in which sensory data, models of phenomena, artificial intelligence and the power of rational decisions are backed up by normative decision theories. ICRA data collection in Section 2 enables the estimation of many subsequent parameters. Fire dynamics can be calculated using models such as [11,26,7] The results from these models, the localization of civilians and evacuation models allow the estimation of the possible course of action or: conditions of nature in other emergency situations. Data from the Incident Data Reporting System allow the evaluation of probabilities of these states. Data from fire department localization, activity reporting and psychophysical conditions allow a better assessment of the real availability of real human resources.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: The emerging paradigms of cyber-physical systems allow large amounts of data to be collected and processed on an unprecedented scale, greatly increasing the perception of machines, which face the obstacles that sustain the status quo (naturalistic decision-making) of emergency decision-making. On the other hand, the results of the descriptive decision theory contradict the assessment that humans make predominantly rational decisions, forcing the search for new solutions based on computer systems and rational decision-making. A normative decision theory is strongly rooted in the paradigm of rational decision-making. It advises on how humans should really make decision.The paper proposes a framework for the search for new solutions in the normative and prospective domains. It also enables a comparison between human (naturalistic) decision-making and computerized (normative) decision-making. The basis for this framework is derived from the ICRA project.
